clean_text: This paper describes the parameters and tagsets (analogous to "Dialogue Act" tagging (Stolcke et al2000)), which they and three other groups have developed for this highly specialised domain.

raw_text: These are similar to some of the Dialogue Act labels used in NLP work: Stolcke et als (2000) agreement, response acknowledgement, summarize, or VERBMOBIL? s suggest, confirm, clarify (Jekat et al1995)

raw_text: Stolcke et al (2000) used HMMs as a general model of discourse with an application to speech acts (or dialog acts) in conversations
clean_text: Stolcke et al (2000) used HMMs as a general model of discourse with an application to speech acts (or dialog acts) in conversations.

raw_text: These notions have been particularly fruitful in the dialog community, where dialog act tagging is a major topic of research; to cite just one prominent example: (Stolcke et al, 2000)
clean_text: These notions have been particularly fruitful in the dialog community, where dialog act tagging is a major topic of research; to cite just one prominent example: (Stolcke et al, 2000).

raw_text: Stolcke et al (2000) point out that the use of dialogue acts is a useful first level of analysis for describing discourse structure
clean_text: Stolcke et al (2000) point out that the use of dialogue acts is a useful first level of analysis for describing discourse structure.

raw_text: We chose 12 tags by manually labelling the dialogue corpus using tags that seemed appropriate from the 42 tags used by Stolcke et al (2000) based on the Dialog Act Markup in Several Layers (DAMSL) tag set (Core and Allen, 1997)
clean_text: We chose 12 tags by manually labelling the dialogue corpus using tags that seemed appropriate from the 42 tags used by Stolcke et al (2000) based on the Dialog Act Markup in Several Layers (DAMSL) tag set (Core and Allen, 1997).

raw_text: A super set of dialogue acts that covers all domains would necessarily be a large number of tags (at least the 42 identified by Stolcke et al (2000)) with many tags not being appropriate for other domains
clean_text: A super set of dialogue acts that covers all domains would necessarily be a large number of tags (at least the 42 identified by Stolcke et al (2000)) with many tags not being appropriate for other domains.

raw_text: Another main approach to robust dialogue processing has been statistical mod els for identifying dialogue acts (e.g., Stolcke et al (2000))
clean_text: Another main approach to robust dialogue processing has been statistical models for identifying dialogue acts (e.g., Stolcke et al (2000)).

raw_text: For instance, Stolcke et al (2000) explore n-gram models based on transcribed words and prosodic in formation for SWBD-DAMSL dialogue acts in the Switchboard corpus (Godfrey et al, 1992)

raw_text: (Stolcke et al, 2000) reports an impressive 71% accuracy on transcribed Switch board dialogues, using a tag set of 42 DAs
clean_text: (Stolcke et al, 2000) reports an impressive 71% accuracy on transcribed Switchboard dialogues, using a tag set of 42 DAs.
